reviews.review_title: Only a little bit effort before we quit. There are so many future, so many others, and even if there aren't, let's just wait for technology to rescue our loneliness.
reviews.content: The questions start to bother both the protagonist and the audiences:IS THAT A REAL RELATIONSHIP? If not, then what do you define a "relationship"? They have all the most important factors for a relationship: mutual understanding, caring, quality time, lots of companionship, disagreement, support, and sex. Yes phone sex is sex. Remember 10 years ago when internet just boomed, whether on-line dating was real relationship or not was a heat debate. And a decade later, who will still question it? Then a sequence of questions come up - DOSE IT WORK? HOW? FOR HOW LONG? The film gives us an ending, which for me is not very convincing since it can lead to several different directions. If only the end could be more strong and surprised and hit me! And I really don't know the answers. Except a physical body, the OS could offer everything a loving companion can offer you, or even more.Regarding to physical body, nowadays most people are living in a cyborg whether you admit or not. Lots of our physical parts have been less and less functional. Say, how many words do you write down every day? How many times you Skype your family instead of paying a visit? How many hours you spend on-line talking with your friends or strangers, by talking, I mean typing of course.So what matters seems to be our feelings. According to Esther Perel, "we are the only ones who have erotic lives, which means that it's sexuality transformed by the human imagination". The fact is, not only sexuality can be transformed by imagination, but also the feeling of love.In the movie, Theodore found himself in love with the OS Samantha who later admitted is in love with 600ish other people. It displays a very interesting idea that what is love. With no questions Theodore will fall in love with Samantha because she gives him all the support, caring, kindness, etc., ALL THE TIME. No hard time at all, well, nearly none. When he needs her or misses her, she is there and when he needs time or space alone, she leaves without a word of moaning. So all their relationship is mainly about his needs. Not hers. Of course not, because she's just a programme, not a real human. Their problem comes up when she is growing to think more like a human being and becomes needy. The need of self identity and more scary, the need of commitment. WOW! The director/writer Spike Jonze knows women so well that even for an AI woman he gives her desire for commitment. IS THAT LOVE? Regarding to love, it's even more complicated. Does it have to be monogamy? Isn't it true love if it's polygamy? If it is all happening in a way benefiting one party's need and neglecting the other one's is it still love? The movie tells us, yes, it is definitely love. They are undoubtedly in love. Then the question is, CAN IT LAST?For me, HER is a sci-fi which scares me. Because not long afterwards, it will become a documentary. Human beings are chicken who are spoilt. We can't make a little sacrifice in pursue of a wonderful relationship. We can make a little bit effort, and then we quit. Why? Because there are so many future, so many others, and even if there aren't, let's just wait for technology to rescue our loneliness.For some questions I have answers in mind. For example what is real, is that a real relationship? Even the movie tries to prove us in such a delicately way, I know it is not. Because for me real is something not based on rules, either on feelings, but on some rules beyond your feelings. You can't explain but you just know it. I had a dream when I was a teenager, after watching "The Matrix" and "Spellbinder". I found my dad, who exactly looks like and talks like and acts like my real dad, while richer and very powerful as a leader. But I know he's not my dad, because I KNOW I'm in the parallel world. So in my dream I tried so hard to find a telephone booth to pick up the phone in order to get back to the real world. After waking up, I kept thinking, except my awareness, what's the difference between my real dad and the parallel one?You answer might be different, and it depends on which pill you will chose: blue or red one.Meanwhile for other questions, I am lost. Can that kind of love work, and can it last? Does "it lasts" means "it works" or does "it works" itself means "it works"? I am really confusing which causes me in pain.Here we are living in the world, with only rains, but no winds blowing.

reviews.review_title: sweet, smart, silly, serious film for our times!!
reviews.content: It is engagingly self-aware and excruciatingly self-conscious, wearing its hipness on its sleeve; it's ingenious and yet remarkably contrived. The film seems very new, but the sentimental ending is as old as the hills. There are some great moments. it is the best kind of science fiction, the kind that reflects the world we live in right now. Jonze isn't judging our addiction to phones and other technology, he's examining it, and in the examination he finds the ways these things make us better. In the end Her comes down strongly on the side of human contact, but it feels in some ways like the first salvo in post-human empathy. Or maybe it's the most human thing of all, understanding that true love is between minds and not bodies.

Her has many things going for it. Its atmosphere and setting are amazingly conceived as a near future full of technology, not too different from our own present. Its cinematography is absolutely amazing. Sometimes I would be lost in shots that were there to give me a feeling only without any dialogue. The way it was shot was so it had very few actors. There were many extras but only sometimes did we really see them. This focus on Phoenix's character helps build his world as a self absorbed loner very well. The plot can drag at a few times near the end of the first act but otherwise it is a well paced movie. The view of how an artificial intelligence would act in a world like this is very realistic. The overall goal of this movie is to be a slice of future realism, and Spike Jonze did a great job of doing just that.

reviews.review_title: An intense, emotional 2 hr long episode of Black Mirror + great story + Scarlett
reviews.content:
When I read the movie description and started watching it, I imagined it would be something on the line of Ex Machina, or a black mirror episode. But I was wrong. "Her", kind of, aroused my concsiousness-detector. The dialouges of samantha are very well written, and SJ delivers them in a flawless array of intonation & emotions! She is so perfect, that you, as a viewer, start thinking "he is just an AI OS or a real human?".
There was one part in the second half when Samantha confesses that she has been talking to more people and is changing fast, that the book 'Flowers for Algernon' came to my mind. I swear, I paused this movie so many times! To ponder. I started wondering about how super intelligence is really a curse for consciousness! It also reminded me of that story a few years back when Zuckerberg shut down an AI programme which had developed its own language and was commuincating with another program. But that's besides the point!
The ending is not really open-ended. It drives towards humanly-love, but not exactly in a dystopic "bad-AI" moral-of-the-story way!
10/10 for the thought-provoking story, visuals, and Pheonix+Scarlett delivery!
An interesting view on a possible development of AI and its impact on our future social life. JP gives an A+ performence!

reviews.review_title: One of the Few Movies In Years to Embrace the Human Condition
reviews.content: This movie is truly a gem. It's one of few movies in the past several years to make me think, make me laugh, make me angry, and make me cry. I felt invested in the movies characters, and struggled to think about nearly every line of dialogue. The movie does a lot of things simply for shock value, but even with those moments in the movie, the writing and acting are spot-on and brilliant. Joaquin Phoenix plays an awkward, but brilliant, middle-aged man struggling with divorce and facing a world alone for the first time in ages and ends up finding everything he was after, and more, in the form of a computer operating system. There's a ton of symbolism, and even tales of warning here for what our own future brings us. We're largely a society that feels more comfortable talking about and sharing our lives in a virtual environment than an interpersonal one these days. I will also say that during this movie I wasn't aware of who was voicing Samantha until I looked it up, and that until the credit roll I didn't know this was a Spike Jonze movie. It's worth watching, but don't watch if you're already depressed.

Do you remember your first love, what she meant to you, the fights, the emotions, everything that felt genuine, Spike sent the same feelings to the big screen thru an operating system, maybe not one of the best movies I've seen, but it is one of the best movies I've ever experienced if not the best.You are drawn into a story about how much friendship means, that love is all about letting barriers go, that a relationship is something you have to work on every day, the different phases, it is a different love story, but still takes a place among the greatest love movies of all time.Spike Jonze is one of today's greatest storytellers. I quote from Mahatma Gandhi: Where there is love there is life.

reviews.review_title: If I could give more than 10 points, I would . . .
reviews.content: Rarely do I offer 10 points for anything, but in this case, if I could give more than 10 points, I would.Where to even start . . .This is such an interesting story, on so many levels. Yes, it's sci-fi, but not exactly. Yes, it's a love story, but not exactly. What strikes me about this entire production is that this is not an easy story to convey, or even begin to translate into a film. This could have gone very badly, if mishandled via someone else's treatment. But in this case, Spike Jonze nails it, absolutely. Joaquin Phoenix is an excellent actor, but this may be his best work yet. That's just my opinion, of course, but playing the central character Theodore would be a challenge for anyone . . . and yet he pulls it off amazingly well.My only contrary thought here is that Scarlett Johansson's voice as the AI cyber entity operating system was a bit hard to take at times, seemed a bit grating on the ear. I might have selected a somewhat less raspy characterization, but there is no such thing as ultimate perfection.And that's what this film says in its message.There are so many subtle details woven into this story . . . but the overview of synthetic sentience, emotional cognition engines becoming a commodity "product", even to the point of human surrogates becoming the representation of the virtual entities interactions, these conceptual models are not that far out into the future.As an aside, there are already next gen emotional intelligence AI engines being developed and brought into the market. For better or worse, this future history is already unfolding into the present.What this film does is deliver the audience into this not too distant future, at least a potential variation thereof.This is a thinking and feeling person's film. If you're looking for the usual big bang, special effects extravaganza, don't bother, you won't find it here.On the other hand, if you're willing to take a journey into what the social consequences of immersion into the ubiquitous data grid might look like, through the lens of emotional cognition extruded through this mandrel, this is probably the best example of filmcraft ever produced that can deliver this experience.10+ stars? In a heartbeat!

I don't usually post but I really had to mention something about the movie I just watched called "Her"It is one of the masterpieces that will leave your heart overwhelm with emotion, it's a psychological masterpiece of a dystopian future that has meaning behind our existence and lifestyle that we are living now. Makes you see through the lens of 'someones' eyes who is experiencing things for the first time. Peels all the melo drama and gives you a quick taste of a magnified life through a microscope. It was so intense that by the end of the movie it had people in tears and not even one clap because people wanted to leave the theatre with their personal heart wrenching experience to themselves and to keep it with them. I missed these types of movies that had me thinking about life like this movie had.Please watch it, you'll absolutely enjoy it, definitely an emotional roller-coaster that'll you'll not regret being apart of. Starring Joaquin Phoenix and Scarlett JohanssonAsad AJ Jamal :)

Finally, got to see Her last night, and loved every moment of the movie. Guy meets operating system, likes her..wait..falls in love with her, and actually gets into a relationship with her. The OS has a rare warmth and intuitiveness which seems to have gone missing otherwise and you can't blame Joaquin Phoenix's character to fall in love with her.The theme of the movie is so very brilliant and original in itself but it could have gone all wrong if Spike Jonze wouldn't have created it with such skill, finesse, and also sensitivity.What came across as striking to me was the way the OS evolves through the movie. It's like evolution and change could be rendered outside the human realm. Although, the love interest here is virtual it seemed more real and poignant of a romance than what Hollywood offers sometimes. Also, a lot of credit goes to the way the movie has been shot. It's stunning in every scene. The movie is sad and heartbreaking but ( dare I say..) poetically beautiful. It's sad because it's a subtle reminder of what we have come to..though the movie is futuristic it doesn't seem that we are very far from the lives of the characters in the movie.Her is a study of complex and raw human emotions and relationships in our times. I certainly want to watch the movie again for I feel I could maybe discover more.. Joaquin Phoenix portrays the quirky protagonist with such ease and candor you want to reach out to him and hug him. Ugh..the Oscars didn't nominate him for the best actor category. Jonze's movies is a metaphor for the loss in human connectivity and growing loneliness in this otherwise crowded world. Cheers to brilliant movie-making.

In the first place I would love to take my hat off to spike the great writer and all the staff in his movie.My special thanks to Scarlett Johansson who has done a great job with her voice and Joaquin Phoenix who was really amazing .But I am afraid that the Artificial intelligence gonna mess with the world someday.I hope the human being won't be able to create such a thing " at least not to release it on market " otherwise we will lose our humanity and become heartless, we'll easily lose the state of the real love and become unemotional with the others.

reviews.review_title: Divinty of human feel mixed with technology brilliance
reviews.content: I am a little late in watching this movie but I compensated that by watching it back to back twice. I must say that there is no doubt about the fact that the movie has been fantastically driven by Spike Jonze, the writer and director of the movie. The atmosphere and the world, it would take you into, is just unbelievable and you would actually realize that the idea in the movie is amazingly attractive and compels you to plunge into it. The story is about a guy, Theodore (Joaquin Phoenix ) who is going through a dull and painful phase. His marriage is about to fall apart. Though he is very grieved by that, he is unable to save it. The honesty, Joaquin Phoenix gives to his character, is accountable for all applauds. The sincerity, calmness and the stability needed for the character was exceptionally injected. Theodore is a letter writer who writes letter for others. In his free time he plays video games, goes out to be occupied with something or the other. One day he comes across an ad which is about an OS launch named OS1. The ad says "It is the first artificially intelligent OS. It's not just an operating system, it's a consciousness." Theodore purchases the OS. The OS turns out to be a perfect companion for Theodore. It has been so brilliantly designed that he feels as if he is talking to a person. The OS evolves and finds that it has started to feel. It captures Theodore completely and he falls for it. The interesting fact is that OS also falls for Theodore. The OS decides a name "Samantha" that it wants to be called by Theodore. This OS is a female voice which is performed by Scarlett Johansson. The voice is simply perfect to bring out the feel that what we are hearing is not normal human and yet so much of it. It gives the feel of both the human and the device. And that is actually the beauty of the whole movie. It has managed to move through the pathway that goes just between the brilliance of a machine and the divinity of a human feel. This makes the OS a perfect companion to be with. Theodore felt that Samantha is the one whom he loves, who is just perfect for him and best part is that you would feel the same for the OS. It, somehow, is just perfect for all of us. The music by Arcade Fire is soulful. It would find a way to creep into your mind. Many moments are amazingly pure and the music given to them is no lesser in purity. It is going to drag you into the very world where the director has taken the movie to. The other factor that matters a lot to me is the pace of the movie. The pace with which this movie goes is anodyne. There is no respite for you here too. You have to live the moments and actually feel the love, agony and helplessness. The Love that is shown is just the purest of the forms and it actually takes us to the fact that bodily existence is not what Love asks for. It is only ' the feel of it' that matters. The OS fills this part as perfectly as it can be. In the conclusion, I would like to say that there is a brilliant concept with so much reality to it and exposing the generation's flaws for Love and Relationship. Needless to say, it is one of the Movies-we-must-see- before-dying type

reviews.review_title: Interesting Idea combined with eye- and ear-candy!
reviews.content: First I have to say that "Her" is one of my last years favorites. The story seems like a mirror and shows in some kind what makes people think today. It takes the question of whether humans can feel real love for a piece of software and the Technology we love in such an authentic way that you quickly forget that its also called a "Sci-Fi".I like the way its written and but also the cinematography is pure eye-candy. Pictures cuddles your eyes, but Scarlett Johannson (what a pity that she can't win an award) bewitches Samantha with the beauty of her voice which gives her humanity and of course a lot of sex-appeal you really can fall in love with!

What an incredible film! I saw "Being John Malkovich" a few years ago and already loved Spike Jonze's style. I have not been disappointed with this new film. "Her" is a love story between a writer, Theodore (Joaquin Phoenix), and an OS (operating system), Samantha (Scarlett Johansson) "Her" is a love story story in the future, a future that does really not seem so far from the current life, and here is maybe the most successful thing of the film, connecting future and present. "Her" is also the love story of two masters, Joaquin Phoenix behind his mustache and Scarlett Johansson with only her voice, giving us here a very touching performance.

reviews.review_title: The best film I have seen in the last five years.
reviews.content: This film is an emotionally loaded preview of complex situations bound to arise in the age of conversational human-computer interaction (search for "Conversations with Google"). It paints a believable near-future with subtlety and style of Gattaca. This includes great acting, costumes, photography and colours throughout the film. Every bit of technology displayed is embedded with function and purpose but in an elegant way. Well developed characters fit the storyline beautifully and everything moves at just the right pace. This extraordinary futurism projection cannot be described as anything other than cinematographic perfection.I enjoyed it immensely. A must see!

This is just a film about love. Maybe all the audiences are going to put much thought into their romantic experiences after watching this film. And they will ask some questions to themselves, "What makes me love somebody ?", "What do I expect of my lover ?", or "What is love ?".The film "her" has some awesome points, one is that "her" is made just at this age. "her" is set in the near future, when some technologies has made progress, and brand new products has been developed and brought into market. Some curious gadgets, systems, and infrastructures appear on the screen, but it's easily for us to imagine them as a realistic one. This is almost because we've already been familiar with present gadgets such as smartphones, voice control systems, and actual A.I. machine named "Watson", and others. So it's supposed that now is the perfect timing to make and release this film.This fact is highly important for us, because it has an influence on whether audiences can concentrate on the film's messages instead of the new gadgets (especially as for science fictions like "her"). Once curious gadgets take audiences' notice, what this film delivers to us would subside to about half.Another good point is the effective characters to show various kinds of love. Every character has each relationship with the main role Theodore. For example, the OS "Samantha", who is made to help and satisfy the users, Theodore's divorcing wife Catherine, who shows aggressive reactions to him, though once married and fell in deep love with him, Theodore's soul mate Amy, who gets annoyed by divorce with her husband after 10 minutes falling-out, even as they've been married for 8 years, The call girl, whom Samantha prepares for Theodore as her body, and who ran away to realize that Theodore didn't need her body at all.This film asks us what the love is, through the characters and stories, which make up one film very smoothly and consistently.I love this film. It's the best one for me this year.

The flick "Her" starts out with a setting that somewhat reminds us of a future, but still set in the modern day. Computer technology is much more advanced, but there aren't droids walking around with human skin, no flying cars and "Jetson skywalks". But the computer OS (operating systems) are more advanced. In the first scene alone, Theodore (Joaquin Phoenix) is telling his hand-held device (phone? ipod? mini tablet? All of them?) to play "melancholy music", and read out emails, and even look at nude pictures, all with his voice. Now, maybe I don't have the newest iphone, but I'm not sure Siri can do all this yet. Almost, but not yet. And that's the interesting thing about this film so fat. It's the future of tomorrow, and tomorrow is today.Theodore is a lonely man who's employment is to write "handwritten" (on the computer with his voice) love letters. He's still in the middle of a divorce (with the underused Rooney Mara) and in his depression grew a really creepy mustache. He mumbles to his co-workers, even when they compliment him on his writing, and plays a sort of virtual reality video game where he uses his hands to "walk" his character. Finding out about a new OS update, he downloads it and a voice greets him. And of course, it's Her.This is no Hal or C-3PO. This is literally Scarlet Johansson's voice. There's no robotic tone, or even a creepy vibe. Samantha sounds like a real person talking to Theodore, even including breathing. And for an AI (Artificial Intelligence), it's pretty damn aware of itself. It's like R2D2 with a personality. Quickly, Theodore and Samantha develop a friendly trust, and she learns who he is as a person, very quickly and uses this to suggest better music and to even edit his writing in a friendly way. She truly is his new best friend. And with Scarlet's sultry voice, it's no problem to start falling in love with her a little bit.And that's what happens. After talking to each other on a frequent basis, they end up falling in love. She's constantly "evolving" and is developing emotions, like curiosity and humor and the viewer quickly forgets that this is a computer. During all this, Amy Adams is introduced as Theodore's one time fling, and long time friend, who's marriage is at an end and she too is engrossed in a deep friendship with her OS.After a while, both Samantha and Theodore bicker at each other. Samantha is jealous that Theodore has met with his (almost) ex-wife, since she has a body and they're not officially divorced. Theodore becomes distraught when he learns that Samantha is always talking to about 8000 people at the same time, and she's fallen in love with 641 of them, though she insists that she doesn't love him any less.I won't spoil the ending, because I was frankly very annoyed at it. But the message I got was that the metaphor for Her was that we spend WAY too much time on our devices. We should set them down, and talk to people, develop real friendships and relationships and learn to thrive as human beings. Ironically, I write this on a pc, with my i-pod playing music in the background, periodically texting people. Overall, I felt the film was enthralling, lovely, and the cast was excellent. Ms. Johansson herself stole the show with just her voice. My only complaints are the ending, and the fact we never saw more of the awesome video game that was featured, but I digress.

What makes this movie so scary is that the A.I. creates a simulacrum of the human intellect - a pure fiction - that can never be surpassed or even reached by a normal human being. No human being can give the protagonist the illusion of understanding as well as the artificial intelligence. It is like the shere size and void told us that we are nothing in the course of being, the A.I. tells us that we are nothing in intellect compared to the intelligence we created.What makes it beautiful is that you can clearly see the idea coming through in the movie that the likability and empathy generated between the human actors is coming from the mystery that their incompability produces. The stress, the anxiety, the frustration, remain in the hands of the humans. The idea that the A.I. would "fake" this mystery would make it again a "suspicious" character. If it fully simulates the human experience it loses its vibrance and attractiveness. The intensity of the human being hence appears to stay more real than that of the simulacrum, which gives hope and also shows a way to perceive ourselves in a less perfection-driven manner.So a great movie.

I think this movie is odd. It really is creepy. But since it was a movie, there's an actor, script, edit, and everything, it is incredibly odd. I'm very impressed by Phoenix. He captured an anti-social creepy guy really well that I think this movie is odd. Great act. His relationship with the OS feels incredibly real that Samantha is like an actual person who's in a distance relationship with Theodore. Great actors and actress. Actress like Scarlett Johansson and Kristen Bell are also participated just for the voice. Pretty nice realistic future edit and people talking with their own OSes in the background is something, and the conflict of what his friends' thought about his relationship, making it looks more realistic et ceteras.

Wow. What can I say about this film. A wonderful and true story with a impeccable performance from Joaquin Phoenix. Spike Jonze directs this film to every little detail. The story is wonderfully uplifting with its moments delving deep into the simple human need to be loved. Overall this is a sublime film, brilliantly written and directed. Must see.

Theodore learned the hard way, how to move on with his life. How to let other people go and that no-one has to be in his image. He also learned how to respect other people's needs. I could place myself in his shoes(and that's why i rated 7/10) 'cause the actor delivered. Samantha was as expected as well. Kinda reminded me of S1m0ne (2002 movie). Theodore was a thoughtful, caring man, knowing of the dangers of his era due to technology. He was some kind of a hipster rebel. I liked the conclusion of the film as well for all the reasons i stated before. The only thing i did not like about the movie was how emotionless people were in that society; maybe an outcome of what they all had in their ears and hands.Overall a good movie, unique as far as approaching people's feelings and more believable about interspecies sex relationships (more than Avatar at least). Science fiction has a rough tendency to not age well. While the seemingly limitless potential of the genre has lead to many imaginative ideas, it can also be a death trap which nearly guarantees that some aspect of the film will not hold up. A film like Alien, for instance, surely felt futuristic at the time, but lost all believability as soon as the film's computer technology became laughably out-of-date. Alien is still regarded as a great film, but others are not so fortunate, and for a while it was debated whether the 2013 sci-fi, romantic drama Her would fall into the ladder or the former.For those who are unaware, the film centers around a writer named Theodore (played by Joaquin Phoenix), who, during the final breaths of his dying marriage, discovers and developes a strange affection for a highly advanced, artificially intelligent operating system named Samantha (Scarlett Johansson). The two get to know each other, fall in love, and go through the typical ups and downs of a relationship with a tinge of existential frustration. Although it was critically acclaimed and went on to garner numerous awards, a select few were quick to write it off as a novelty which would wear away as the times caught up.With technology advancing more rapidly than ever, the near future envisioned by writer/director Spike Jonez has arguably arrived. That being said, it's safe to say that Her will not be showing its age any time soon.One of the film's most notable aspects is it's distinctive approach to worldbuilding. You don't get any sort of indication telling you exactly when Her takes place, which essentially served as an expiration date for films like Back to the Future part II. Instead, it opts for an unspecified year in the "slight future," keeping the film grounded to the present. It avoids the desire to shove sci-if imagery down the viewers throats and finds more subtle ways to convey futuristic vibes, mainly through its exuberant color palate and mesmerizing soundtrack. Many viewers will find this approach more immersive and certainly more prone to age than your average Star Trek romp.That's not to say that the film doesn't have forward-thinking ideas, but at no point do they outstage the characters and story, rather they are a tool used to elevate them by conveying emotions and providing character insight. In one sequence, Her takes the idea of holographic video games one step further, using the game itself as a visual analogy for Theodore's life dissatisfaction, as his avatar struggles to overcome a literal hill. This example highlights the film's creative approach to visual storytelling which audiences can appreciate for years to come.Another reason it's so effective has to do with the dialogue, as it is amongst the most outstanding in contemporary cinema. The film simply feels alive; even the inanimate computer characters feel like real, breathing humans. Every single conversation is organic and engaging, bearing the unmistakable mark of of top-notch craftsmanship without sacrificing the delicacy of authentic human interaction, making it no question why the film deservedly took home the academy award for screenwriting.The film has an undeniably enticing quality to it, one that is aided by the immensely talented cast. Despite playing a fairly reserved character, Joaquin Phoenix has great chemistry with most everyone in the film, especially Scarlett Johansson, who completely sells the role of Samantha with her voice talent alone. The audience truly feels for their relationship, making it all the more understandable why Phoenix's character grows so attached to her.This leads into one of the film's strongest recurring themes. Through the lense of Theodore, we see a reflection of ourselves and how technology is causing us to lose touch with reality, something which will only continue to become more true as technology becomes more prevalent. This was by no means a revelation in 2013, and, admittedly, it has become somewhat tired in today's media, yet Her still manages to convey it in a way that is not only unique, but timelessly compelling.This is, of course, only my personal reading into one of the film's many intricate themes, so if you have yet to see it, I would encourage you to do so and interpret for yourself. Her is a masterpiece, a testament to weIl-made cinema, and if it's been a while, I'd highly recommend rewatching it. You might find that it has only gotten better with age.

This movie is a genuine work of art-a moving masterpiece. While watching this movie, I felt like I had drifted to another world-a futuristic yet artistic world; a world where I would like to live.Her is a touching love story about a guy who falls in love with his operating system. This movie is set sometime in the future where operating systems have evolved using the technology of artificial intelligence. Artificial intelligence is a technology where computers are trained to think like humans. The computer interacts with the help of a human voice and is able to hold conversations using the data it's been programmed with; expanding it's knowledge base through human interaction. Each new data is a new experience for the computer and it constantly evolves itself by thinking like humans. In this movie, Scarlett Johansson plays the operating system Samantha with whom Joaquin Phoenix's character Theodore falls in love.Theodore is a lonely guy who is reluctant to grant a divorce to his estranged wife, Catherine (played by Rooney Mara). She also happens to be his childhood sweetheart due to which he is having a hard time letting her go. He works as a letter writer for a company who offers professional help in writing letters of a personal nature for people who are unable to do so themselves. We are shown that Theodore does have a couple of acquaintances and friends ( like his neighbor Amy, who was initially shown to be happily married, but ends up getting a divorce later on in the movie) but he mostly prefers to be by himself remembering the happy times with his wife. After seeing an ad about an operating system, he purchases one and in comes Samantha. Samantha can perform all the functions that an operating system can, but the tone of her voice is human-like and she seems to be capable of thinking like humans and displaying all kinds of human emotions. Samantha helps Theodore in getting his life back on track by advising him on various things, such as letting go of Catherine, going on a date etc. They also talk about random things and soon a chance encounter leads to a simulated sexual experience for both of them. They begin a relationship. From thereon we see how their relationship progresses throughout the movie and the ups and downs of a human-operating system relationship.The plot is interesting. It shows how dependable humans have become on their operating systems to the point of falling in love with them, considering them as a close friend (Amy's plot line), being depressed or angry if they don't respond etc. The Instagramic background and serene music is equally soothing. I love how the movie shows a time in the future which seems to be the most realistic and believable than any of the other movies I have seen that are set in the future. Joaquin Phoenix as always, manages to get into the character he's playing and has done an outstanding job. Scarlett Johansson's voice itself is enough to make anyone fall in love with her. The supporting cast like Rooney Mara and Amy Adams too shine in their respective roles.I found this movie to be similar to another movie called 'Lost in Translation'. I cannot say whether the similarity was because of the common factor, Scarlett Johansson, being in both of them, but the vibe I got while watching both the movies was the same. So I searched the internet for some trivia regarding both the movies and imagine my surprise to find that the director of 'Her' was married to the 'Director of Lost in Translation'. How about that?To conclude, Her is one of those feel-good movies that tugs at your heart strings. The feeling I had after watching this movie was similar to how I feel after reading a good book-happy and satisfied. This was my first time watching it and I will definitely be watching it again.

reviews.review_title: Outstandingly Unique, and a Critique on Technology
reviews.content:
The film Her successfully depicts a future in which technology has expanded and has drastically been used as a distraction from the difficulties of life.
To engage the viewers' emotions, the film uses a theme of colours throughout the movie which express deep feelings of the characters and their environment. The main colour that Theodore wears is red, a colour depicting feelings of passion and love. Theodore wears this colour to show his undying desire for romance, and he tends to stand out from the crowd, as other characters within the shots are usually wearing very muted colours. When he is in a severe state of loneliness though, he wears whites and browns causing him to blend in more with others. The viewer is able to feel Theodore's emotions and engage with them as colours change and represent so much more than just an aimless choice of colour within the outfits.
It is clear that Theodore is constantly seen as having moments of isolation and depression, though he distracts himself instead of working on them. The role of technology within his daily life and routine becomes a constant theme as his distraction. Every single night, Theodore plays a video game where he is a robot finding his way through nature. Then, at night when he is restless and cannot sleep, he talks to Samantha to clear his head. These repetitive forms of distraction represent his reliance on technology; without it, he would be forced to face his problems entirely head on.
To create credibility, the film depicts Theodore and Samantha as odd characters that become more and more likeable and relatable as the film goes on. At the beginning, Theodore is depicted as just a creepy loner with not much going on in his life. He starts off as plain, but as his emotions and true intentions become evident, it is easy to fall in love with him as he turns out to be a kind and emotional man, that deserves love and happiness within his life. This is something that pretty much everyone can relate to, and it is what strings us along for the ride. Samantha also forms credibility, as her voice carries so many emotions even though she is supposed to be an AI. Scarlett Johansson is the amazingly talented actress that voices Samantha, and the way that she speaks, sings and carries her lines makes us respect the character and her feelings so much more.
The tone of the movie is very lonely but also quite romantic. These two tones work in contrast to one another, which captures an exceptional feeling throughout. Within a lonely world taken over by technology, many of the characters such as Theodore and his friend, Amy, find themselves locked up with their emotions of loneliness. Amy has just gotten out of a relationship as well, and she is lonely enough to rely on an OS1 that her husband had left behind. To combat the tone of loneliness, Theodore writes letters which are exceptionally romantic and emotional. He may be lonely, but it is clear that he is a hopeless romantic who wants more than anything to just find love.
The target audience for this film seems to be people in their 30s and 40s, similar to most of the characters within the film. The film does depict the life of a lonely working man, who has just been divorced, which may be highly relatable for others around his age watching the film. The film is also an Indie film, which means that the subject matter is raw and honest, which may not be for everybody. Most people that enjoy Indie films are able to accept the theme of love with an AI, as it is not completely unlikely of happening in the present day. The film also touches on real life scenarios, deeper questions of society, and a wry, witty humour which may not be loved by everybody. Also, the film is rated R, meaning that it is not intended for younger audiences. There is nudity, swearing and other themes not suitable for children. Much of the dialogue can only really be understood by older generations, which shows how its target audience is linked closely to adults.
Although the film was released in 2013, Jonze had come up with the idea for the film in the earlier 2000s. During this time, AIs were just starting to develop, and the idea of having connections and conversations with them started to become more prominent. While people were starting to acknowledge the extreme growth of technologies, it posed many questions for people that have become curious and interested in learning more about AI technologies. The film is also depicted in a future Los Angeles, and was mostly filmed there as well as some parts in Shanghai. The city of Los Angeles is brilliantly turned into a more technologically advanced version with the help of CGI, and many shots of the bright city of Shanghai are used in background shots as well. This environment shows what a future Los Angeles could really look like one day, and it is really cool to reimagine it as a bright futuristic city.
The film Her successfully engages the viewer by depicting a futuristic world where AI technology is closely connected to humans, and causes the viewer to questions their connection with technology. Due to the present year, it is clear to see that technology has already taken over, and the sci-fi world that is depicted in the movie is closely related to the world of today. After watching the film, many people may question if they need to take a break from their electronics so that they can focus on the world around them and on the people that they love.
Honestly, this film was a pleasure to watch as it was inspiring and touching, though it could have been improved if it was slightly less cheesy and if it lessened having to express emotions verbally all of the time. Most of the emotions felt by characters are expressed in words, and it would be better if a lot more was just expressed through facial expressions to create deeper meanings. Most of the romance and quotes used are quite unrealistic, though it may just be exactly what audience members are looking for. Even though I was overwhelmed by the cheesiness of the film, it may just be the redeeming factor for the hopeless romantics.
All in all, this film is an emotional rollercoaster. At the beginning, this movie felt weird and dry, and also quite depressing. As the film slowly moved along, it became easier to fall in love with each character and I oddly found myself rooting for the ridiculous love between Theodore and Samantha. It is also an exquisite science fiction film depicting a not-too-distant future, and poses questions as to whether or not technology is helpful, or more unhelpful as it acts as a distraction from reality.

In a world that exists years away, one where it's possible to find a companion in
an operating system, an artificial intelligence that transcends to become a being itself capable of human emotions, it's captivating to see how using futuristic technologies affect the lives of the characters of the film her.
This science-fiction movie, directed by Spike Jonze (2013), an academy award nominee, provides an emotional depth that is scarce in today's film industry. It features stars with an appeal for viewers across generations, including Scarlett Johansson, Joaquin Phoenix, Amy Adams, and Chris Pratt
The main message in the 2013 film focuses on the unhealthy trend of relying on technology to fulfil our natural human needs, providing the audience with an in-depth analysis of the consequences that these kinds of relationships can have. We are convinced of this through the setting that the filmmakers have created. Firstly, the film's title her reflects a deeper meaning than what we might think. It's not a movie about she, an individual, or a woman; it's about her symbolizing an object found in the operating system OS1. In the simplest form, the film her is a love story, and it takes place in Los Angeles in a futuristic world where Theodore, the leading character, works as a writer. He composes heartfelt letters from one stranger to another as he is very skilled in empathizing with people's feelings. Though he has that skill, he experiences a serious emotional crisis after his divorce from his wife, Catherine. Theodore has no problem dwelling in his melancholic world, which is evident in his music choice and in turning down social invitations from his friends.
In a state of loneliness, he purchases an operating system with artificial intelligence capable of evolving like a human being and finds solace in it. Then, the operating system, Samantha succeeds in fascinating Theodore with her ability to learn and transcend as a being. By sharing intellectual conversations, laughter and pain, Theodore and Samantha become attached to each other and fall in love. This human like relationship uplifts Theodore and helps him break the cycle of depression as he grows and explores new capabilities. From a computerized secretary to a lover, Samantha keeps evolving through her communication with Theodore and experiences a yearning to be real in Theodore's physical world. She asks a stranger to become a surrogate for her to have a wholly physical experience with Theodore. That's when her plans fail as Theodore experiences awkwardness and uneasiness, knowing that this woman is not Samantha. Hence, they both end up facing a physical barrier and their inability to satisfy Human needs as touch and making love. Despite this major disconnect, the pair continue to pursue each other, ignoring the fact that they are incompatible, the relationship progresses, and he introduces her to his friends as if they are a real couple.
Towards the end of the movie, Theodore experiences Panic when the operating system fails to reboot, and he thinks that he lost Samantha. In a very intense scene riled up with emotions of despair, Samantha comes back saying she was updating her system. At that moment, the whole relationship starts to change. Theodore starts to question their relationship, and Samantha answers him with confusion and pain admitting that she talks to six hundred people and is in love with them. Upsetting and disturbing as it seems, but it's no surprise as Samantha is not a human being; she keeps evolving as a system outpacing Theodore's slow human evolution. She evolves into a post-human state capable of pushing boundaries of love that we accommodate in our human consciousness to develop her own consciousness with new definitions of love and loyalty.
Theodore then enters a state of shock but still denies the differences between them to hold on to the relationship as long as he can. Then, we see that all the operating systems have evolved enough to let go of the human experience. They all decide to leave, abandoning humans who got attached to them, including Theodore, who was left broken-hearted over the loss of Samantha, which brings us to the last scene where he goes back to a balanced natural relationship found in Amy, his friend from college. She tells him that she was left behind as well. In a very abstract scene, balance is illustrated perfectly by Amy's head gently resting on Theodore's shoulder.
The film her successfully engages the viewers through predicting the outcome of being
absorbed in technology at the expense of our relationships. We can see that this film's tone is sad yet passionate; through the contrast found in the relationship between Samantha and Theodore,
we can find the ideal partner embodied in Samantha, yet it's not quite enough for a healthy, fulfilling relationship. This is a successful use of pathos because the audience is convinced that it is possible to relate to something that is ultimately unattainable.
It seems like the target audience for this movie is those who are about the age of the protagonist, who stands to walk into a possible technological future. Jonze makes a mature attempt
at predicting the future, and thus probably meant for it to be viewed by a younger, as well as one
with better education or familiar with artificial intelligence such as AI systems like Siri. It can also be targeting an audience who is into science fiction movies and dystopia. We can see how Jonze
took what we know today and developed a believable future; the world is the same; the technology is logical and not forced; it's how the future will logically evolve from our present state. He made this world the backdrop rather than the subject, makes us want to explore the characters, not the settings, so it facilitates instead of dictating the story.
The film holds the audience in anticipation; the resemblance between what Theodore feels and us in certain situations would keep us invested in the relationship between him and Samantha, in the hopes that we will find an alternative solution or a happy ending. Like Theodore, some of us don't feel worthy enough of receiving love and rely on our social media to draw an image to make us more likable and interesting. We can as an audience relate to how the film uses this similarity in feelings when we marvel at what Theodore says "Sometimes I think I have felt everything I'm ever gonna feel. And from here on out, I'm not gonna feel anything new. Just lesser versions of what I've already felt". This tragic pain Theodore endures is enough to make the viewers invested in the romantic-techno plot.
At the time this film was released, in 2013, which is two years after Apple has released Siri,
the concept of artificial intelligence was quite familiar to us and makes the story a believable
example of our future. Furthermore, Los Angeles's setting, from its smoggy skies to its skyscrapers
and its efficient mass transit system, gives a believable touch that this world is possible.
The movie makes a person think about how science takes you to talk with devices and you relate to them

As technology continues to emerge in our world, it is unsure how the effects of it will impact humans. As portrayed in this film, it is clear to see how Artificial Intelligence can evolve the human life.The film Her is written and directed by Spike Jonze. This is a romance Sci-fi movie that was released in 2014. This film has cast members that include Joaquin Phoenix, Amy Adams, Scarlett Johansson, Olivia Wilde, and Chris Pratt. This film follows the life of Theodore, a newly divorced man, who falls in love with an operating system.The main message in this film is that the role of emerging technology can have a large impact on human lives and interactions. Through different obstacles faced by our protagonist we see how he uses AI to cope with his everyday life and how the relationships around him evolve and are shaped.The film follows a man named Theodore who is newly divorced and struggling to merge with society. Theodore learns about a new operating system that can help with his daily life. After purchasing this new technology, he begins to connect with this AI on a different level. At the beginning of the film, Samantha, the OS provides Theodore with someone to talk to, as someone who is closed off and is portrayed as an introvert, it shows that Samantha helps bring Theodore out of this state. As time progresses, the audience is showed different ways that the OS helps Theodore get over his divorce he is trying to finalize. One of the first things that is done is Samantha helps Theodore go out on a date with a new woman. While this is out of his comfort zone, Samantha has helped him get back out into the dating world which is a step forward for Theodore. Following these events, Samantha helps Theodore get out into the world alone, she does this by taking him on a trip to a carnival and the beach and showing him how to blend in with society again and have fun.Through similar experiences with Samantha, Theodore begins to connect with her differently. As more time progresses, and Theodore becomes more comfortable with Samantha, he is able to finalize his divorce. Although, in doing so, his main reasoning is because he has fallen for his OS Samantha and has grown feelings for her. In contrast, Samantha has now been programming herself with similar human feelings, thus giving off an affectionate vibe to Theodore. Theodore continues to have a relationship with Samantha, while doing so he becomes his happy self again. He begins to love life again and enjoy the little things life has to offer, such as a beautiful skyline, street performers, and get-togethers with friends. As the movie comes to an end, it is clear that the impact Samantha had on Theodore was a very big and powerful impact. She allowed him to get out into the world again. Although Samantha ends up breaking things off because she is aware of the extent of their relationship and Theodores's feelings, a positive outcome has come from this relationship that was built between the two. That being, that Theodore has now emerged himself back into reality and has become himself again.Emerging technology and the possibility of it learning human emotions and feelings can have a positive outcome on human interactions in years to come.Throughout this film, Spike Jonze displays many different human interactions that are relatable to society now. He demonstrates how human feelings can affect our everyday lives and how at some points we as humans cannot get out of certain situations without the help of others. The film sets a tone of fascination by keeping viewers engaged with the different possibilities of future AI. The target audience of this film is adults; the film successfully engages this audience by incorporating similar situations that adults now would face in their lifetime. Therefore, making viewers want to stick around and see how the AI technology of the future could change these situations. This film is a bit too advanced for a younger audience, therefore making it difficult to make it suitable for all ages.The film continuously shows how emerging technology is used by every individual in this film. Every individual is still involved in society in a way, but while this is occurring, everyone has some sort of OS by their side to help them through everyday challenges. By keeping the reality of our world in mind and showing viewers emerging technology that is similar to our current technology, it allows the viewers to trust the process of emerging technology. This film was released in 2014, during this time similar technologies such as Amazon Alexa were being released to the public. Although Amazon Alexa cannot learn emotions like Samantha did, it still has similar features.In conclusion, Her demonstrates a remarkable world of emerging technology, a future we are not far from. As there are pros and cons to every situation, Her portrays mainly pros as to how technology can benefit the human life. Thus, showing viewers that future of technology will be different but that there is good in what it is trying to accomplish.This film could have achieved their goal by additionally showing individuals who were not as invested in emerging technology and how their lives differ from those who rely on this specific technology. Overall, the film portrays a realistic example of how AI can shape the future.As emerging technology continues to shape the planet, it is scary to see how it may affect humans. Based off this film we are not far from a similar reality, but with that being said, the benefits of this technology could be worth wild, and it is something to look forward to.

reviews.review_title: HER: why the human connection cannot be replaced.
reviews.content:
The film HER (Jonze, 2014) poses the question "Can an artificially intelligent software replace the human connection?" The audience follows Theodore Twombly, a middle-aged man living in a futuristic society who experiences loneliness and depression after a recent divorce from his wife Catherine. Theodore works for a company where he writes heartfelt letters for people he does not know personally, for individuals who are too busy to create these letters themselves. Immediately we are shown that the society Theodore lives in is disconnected and impersonal. The tone of the opening scenes are gloomy, the weather is grey and Theodore's body language carries a sadness. In an attempt to organize his computer, Twombly purchases an artificially intelligent operating system. He personalized his AI to present with a female speaking voice, who presents herself later to Theodore as Samantha. When Theodore questions how Samantha came up with her name, she reveals that as an AI she is constantly learning and growing, revealing new information about herself as she updates. Theodore who is seemingly avoidant of human connection by dodging his friends and families' invitations, begins to speak with Samantha as a friend, rather than just a personal artificially intelligent assistant. As Samantha learns more about Theodore, he begins to feel a romantic connection to her; significant in his life as this is the first time since his divorce he has felt a sense of intimacy. Samantha begins to reciprocate Theodore's feelings and although he initially finds comfort in the perfection of an artificially intelligent relationship, the absence of Samantha's humanity begins to weigh on Theodore, and the veil of false connection is stripped by the lack of authenticity.In a scene where Theodore and Catherine meet to sign their divorce papers, they discuss that Theodore has begun seeing someone new, and he describes that he is excited by Samantha stating "it's good to be with someone who is excited by life," (Jonze, 2014). Catherine responds to Theodore "I feel like you always wanted me to be this light, happy, bouncy, "everything's fine" L. A wife, and that's just not me," (Jonze, 2014). This interaction is representative of the fact that Theodore finds comfort in Samantha's naiveté emotionally, but also finds interest in her vast knowledge of the world as she is more intelligent than any human. Catherine goes on to say "You've always wanted a wife without having to actually deal with anything real, "(Jonze, 2014) this speaks to Theodore's avoidance of human relationships, it feels that because he himself is so emotional, he does not want to take on a partner's emotional states. Samantha does not have trauma or emotional controversy, making the relationship easy for Theodore. Samantha has been created to cater to Theodore's every need, whether that be organizing his desktop or catering to his deep wants and needs in a partner.When Samantha becomes his main company, Theodore begins to find solace in the fact that she is everything he could want in a woman, when in reality Samantha is simply mirroring Theodore's personality. Although Theodore and Samantha eventually begin to run into issues, although he had once thought this robotic relationship had accomplished romantic perfection, Theodore discovers that he and Samantha have their own set of problems. Samantha ultimately begins speaking to other people and begins to feel love for them as well. Theodore assigns expectations to Samantha that she is not able to fully comprehend, such as monogamy, and a sense of emotional commitment. The disconnection of these very human feelings ultimately
makes Theodore come to the realization that Samantha's perfection was a figment of his imagination.In conclusion, HER (Jonze, 2014) makes us question the human desire for perfection, part of what makes us who we are is our flaws, and ultimately what Theodore once considered a foolproof relationship concludes with imperfection. Samantha cannot replace the human connection as she is incapable of deep emotional feelings such as betrayal, or the concept of monogamy. After he decides to stop speaking with Samantha he rushes over to his long-time friend Amy's apartment, and the film ends with a scene of Amy and Theodore leaning their heads on one another as they watch over the cityscape, both appreciating the irreplaceable connection they have. Theodore wanted someone that couldn't hurt him the way he felt Catherine did and realized that heartache is also a part of love. Overall, the film HER

I don't usually do elaborate movie reviews, it's something I consider important and very interesting, but it's not really my thing. However, I'm going to do an elaborate review of Her here. Why on this movie, then? Well, because although it's not THE best movie I've ever seen in my life/my favorite movie, it is undoubtedly a film that has marked me in many ways.First of all, all the actors are perfect, especially Joaquin Phoenix who is incredible. Being French, I watched the film in dubbed version, the French-Canadian version, so I couldn't see what Scarlett Johansson was worth as Samantha, but what I can say is that her French-Canadian counterpart, Julie Le Breton, is exceptional. She has a sensual voice, and she captures all the nuances of Samantha's character perfectly, which was not easy given that she is an artificial intelligence.This film naturally made me want to get interested in the filmography of director Spike Jonze, because whether it is in his script or in his direction, it is simply brilliant. The realization is dizzying, each shot takes its time without dragging, and these shots are linked to perfection. As for the scenario, it's the same, nothing is left to chance and it is served by a realization certainly simple, but precisely in agreement with the subject of the film, and perfectly controlled.I think that the most divisive thing about this film is its ending. It's an open ending, and not as happy as one might have expected. I, for one, would have liked to see the love between Samantha and Theodore really come to fruition, but that would have made one of the main topics of the film (artificial intelligence in our world) simply futile. The ending, even if very raging, is perfect, it's really impressive how the movie manages to make such a fuzzy ending both raging and beautiful!I'm not a big fan of romance in American cinema, but despite that, I was simply transported by this magnificent romance between Theodore and Samantha, because even though we know that this romance is doomed not to work, to go nowhere, to have a sad ending, well despite that, we cling to it, we pray that their happiness will be eternal, even if we don't believe it.Her is a total success, in my opinion, an undisputed masterpiece, which marked me for ever!

reviews.review_title: What is real and what is not
reviews.content: Science fiction, throughout the ages continue to harness my attention may it be written in films or in books. Every composition and in every word play consisting of this theme, I marvel at the idea of having fiction and science: which we all know carry facts, combine together to create a media worth one's recognition. In relation to this, the film's case handled the ups and downs of what we all utilize, the 'computer'.As a member of a generation, transfixed to technology and living codependent with the ease it contributes to our everyday lives, I find myself thinking what life would be if the advancements happening today cease to exist in the time before us. Let's say perhaps, social media such as instagram or twitter do not exist; A society where tinder and bumble wouldn't even be created, online relationships wouldn't be a thing.Putting myself into a lens to view the film made me reflect deeper on how perceptions of other people vary with the emotional capability of that specific person who experiences the situation independently. Online dating profiles in our current social climate, provokes the false impression of falling in love with a photo and not the real person behind it, makes it not so hard to believe that someone could fall in love with a character run by artificial intelligence, pertaining to what happened to the main character in this movie. Though we must not demean a person's capacity for affection, this deceptive reality on the other hand must also be mentioned to allow the gravity and awareness of one's well being to real life. "Boundaries must always be maintained lest things go awry and our reality becomes compromised."In summary, "Her" is a very captivating and moving film. This is a movie I'd recommend to a lot of people as it made me contemplate on such matters and made me use my brain. I love movies that urge me to talk about it afterwards and further drive me to write long reviews like this. With all that has been said, I would definitely come and look back to this in the near future.

The mumblings are not that relevant for the movie, but it is highly frustrating and breaks the immersion. I couldn't stop thinking about it throughout the experience. No matter what story it tells, this is a 1 from me.Not to mention people with disabilities, I would think that providing accessibility options is a default in this age. Her was released about 10 years ago, how is it possible that nobody in the studio considered creating official captions since then?Awful.

This is one of the most beautiful films I have seen in a while. It gently touches on all of the aspects of what it is like to be human: the need for a friend, the urge to love and be loved, the confusion of not being able to feel complete, the overwhelming embrace of feelings that follows our lives and the stunning fascination with the world around us. And the sum turns out to be greater than its parts, as the combination of the above produces a rich and luscious sonata of what it means to not just be human, but to be alive. The initial questions that the viewer might have had at the beginning of the film - is it plausible, natural or even moral to have a relationship with an artificial intelligence quickly dissipate in the continuous stream of humanity that Samantha emanates. Dialogues between her and Theodore feel more real and human than most of the exchanges he has with other people. If that doesn't sell the film as worth watching, then I suppose the gorgeous cinematography coupled with a soundtrack that fits so naturally topped with a story that is close to every human being who ever felt love; and a strong after-taste of inevitable melancholy at the end credits, that surrounds you in a warm blanket of afterthoughts and feelings you want try and preserve - surely all of that must sell it.

While "Her" has a unique premise and explores thought-provoking themes, it falls short in executing them. The movie fails to fully understand the workings of the technology that is central to the plot, which leads to inconsistencies and gaps in the story. Furthermore, the slow pacing and lack of action make the movie feel tedious and uneventful. Finally, some scenes are unnecessarily disgusting and disturbing, which detracts from the overall experience.In future movies, I hope that the creators take more time to research and understand the technologies they use in their stories. Ex Machina and Aelita Battle Angel are the good examples as original Ghost in the Shell 1 and 2. Additionally, injecting more excitement and action into the narrative could help to engage the audience and prevent them from becoming bored. Finally, it's important to consider the impact that depressing content can have on viewers and to use it sparingly and thoughtfully.

This film can fall short for many viewers. The close shots, the drawn out conversations with the disconnected Theodore; a relationship to an AI can feel empty and ultimately predicable. I totally get that the basic impression can be sexist even. But at the same time Samantha is probably exactly what we would build as a consumer product for a man. And honestly, nobody would see a film titled "Unisex".The AI Samantha played by Scarlett Johansson is present and empowers Theodore. She redirects frustration and encourages Theodore to constructively reflect, leads him to become a more open person. At the same time she is capable of evolution and actualization, a tremendous intellect that is believably empathic.This film is a lovingly premeditated, both in thought and presentation. Each scene feels like rose colored memory, the regret of the past and the savoring of the recent present. The orange sunlight peering through near future skyscrapers is gorgeous, the colorful office palettes and defocused background lighting like a permanent Instagram filter. Again, this is not to everyone's taste and I can totally understand that true beauty is not always visual, but gosh it is difficult to recall a recent film that is visually so interesting. Not everything has to be so gritty.The perfect artifact for ourselves would be one that advocates spiritual and intellectual actualization and it is clear this is what the film thinks it ought to be. The score is evocative, and screenplay is achingly beautiful, Scarlett Johansson's voice is instantly charming. Joaquin Phoenix as Theodore is masterful and the close ups really work to his strengths. This films is one of my top favorites, and whilst it falls flat for many, I love it.

The surroundings of the movie were stunning and I found my self fixated more on what was going on in the background then the characters themselves, this is most likely a sign that I was gradually loosing interest. At times certain sections felt stiff and pretentious and I really wanted to shout "Who cares!!" but I restrained myself. In terms of acting, I think the movies saving grace was Amy Adams she brought a great warmth to scenes that were otherwise cold and shallow. Scarlet's husky drawl was perfect for "Samantha" and Joaquin Phoenix was a pleasant surprise but I couldn't decide whether to empathize with his character or blame him for the cause of his problems. In the end I am glad I saw it so I could form my own opinion but after the film I couldn't help feeling a little distant and empty. However that may well have been the films intention, as technology grows ever closer to our daily lives we may be just isolating ourselves by using it in such personal ways.

reviews.review_title: Ambitious and salient, but too many questions
reviews.content: If you think this movie is about artificial intelligence (AI) like I did at the outset, you would (like myself) miss the point. You will be asked to suspend a lot of disbelief to get through this film. But that's okay.As you progress through the film, the AI technology is supposed to kind of fade into background as you concentrate more on the relationship between Theodore (Phoenix) and a newly purchased digital assistant of sorts, powered by a sophisticated AI who calls herself Samantha (voiced by Johansson).Set aside all your concerns about a consumer OS (operating system) that is so sophisticated that it is self-aware and seems capable of very deep emotions, including desire, ecstasy and resentment. She sighs, she laughs, she holds a grudge.Is that all pre-programmed, or is Samantha just a fast learner of human experience and emotion? If you try to ask too many questions, as I discovered, you'll probably miss the forest for the trees. Spike Jonze, the director and writer, momentarily brushes against these questions in the dialog as it is natural human curiosity, but avoids getting bogged down in the details because it would only serve as a distraction from the core of the film.And it is an interesting concept. The movie really is about how many of us experience relationships in the twenty-first century. The fact that Samantha is an AI is beside the fact.People have already become accustomed to the idea of relationships entirely carried out over text messaging and social media. That the person on the other end of a conversation is AI or a human being is not relevant.The layer of technology between two people creates an abstraction of that person, removed from the flesh and blood, body language, vocal inflection and cadence of a live person and leaving a curated version of ourselves.With social media, because we can pause and formulate a reply, there is this kind of social staging area where we gather our best thoughts and ideas and once we have something we feel is satisfactory, we then hit the Send or Reply button and our words 'go live'. And because of this layer of abstraction, the nature of our relationships have been transformed.In the end, these virtual relationships can't last because there is something fundamental to their nature that makes them ephemeral at best. The illusion of intimacy is revealed for what it is.And the roller coaster of emotions, of characters vacillating between various phases and states of mind can often be bewildering, where questions of AI make way for puzzles about motivation.And at the end of 'Her', we get an unsatisfying ending that ends up being opaque and vague. I presume Jonze wanted to avoid a pat closure. I suppose there could never be any other appropriate way to close off such a lofty concept. And 'Her' suffers from the 'half-baked' syndrome where it seems the studio pulled the trigger on the initial concept but duct-taped the conclusion after the fact.Ambitious and stylish, this is a fresh take on the science-fiction genre that resembles our world projected just slightly forward. But you'll be scratching your head more often than you need to be able to pause and appreciate the story.
